A lot of twists and deaths. I feel like:
***SPOILERS***

TLJ reinvents the themes that Lucas wanted to bring into the Star Wars universe with the prequels. Yes\, Snoke is cut in half like Maul was but that's on purpose. It's not the overt evil that is the true danger but the creeping ordinary-looking Menace which can destroy the galaxy. For the prequels it was a benign and beloved politican from a beleaguered people group who was the real Phantom Menace. For the sequels it's a boyishly wounded\, sulky brooder with the famous bloodline. That decision has angered a lot of fans but it's a deliberate thematic choice and I think a brilliant one. 

People are also incensed that Rey is not from a notable bloodline but just an ordinary local yokel. However that's where Anakin arises in the prequels. He's a super powerful nobody that even the Jedi overlook because of the nowhere place he comes from. The Jedi apparently don't recruit in Tatooine or Jakku. 

Lucas wanted to undermine the idea that your identity is predetermined by your birth or genetics. Great Jedi can come from anywhere and even great Jedi can fall. Luke has a moment of temptation when he embraces the idea that a person can be damned before they make their choices (the "would you kill baby Hitler" conundrum). 

In fact\, most of what is being so criticized in TLJ is Johnson's faithfulness to Lucas's prequel themes.
